Highlights ► Prove the constant volume–capacity ratio property in a general transportation network. ► Investigate the impacts of various regulatory mechanism on the volume–capacity ratio. ► Examine the volume–capacity ratio considering the effect of returns to scale in road construction, discrete road capacity, and link interactions. Abstract It has been addressed in the existing literature that the volume–capacity (v/c) ratio on a private toll road is constant, regardless of the toll value and capacity set by the private companies for each toll road in the network. The previous derivation depends on the assumption that the user equilibrium flow on the private toll road is continuously differentiable with respect to its capacity and toll charge. In this paper, it is shown that the constant v/c ratio phenomenon still holds via relaxing this assumption. Such phenomenon is further examined in different scenarios: the v/c ratio remains constant under the demand regulation, markup charge regulation, and social cost minimization scheme; it may change under the rate-of-return regulation; it may decrease under capacity regulation and increase under the price-cap regulation. Moreover, this paper demonstrates that the v/c ratio may change if there are decreasing or increasing returns to scale in road construction, or the road capacity can only take discrete values, or link flow interactions are involved, whereas the v/c ratio remains constant in case of elastic demand. Keywords Private toll road User equilibrium Volume–capacity ratio Regulation 1 Introduction Consider a general transportation network in which some of the roads are built and operated by individual private firms. Each private firm only controls one road and the concession period is pre-determined to be the road life and the firm simultaneously decides the capacity to construct and the toll rate to charge given its belief on other firms’ choices in order to maximize its profit. The underlying flow distribution is assumed to be in user equilibrium (UE). Xiao et al. (2007) studied both toll and capacity competition in a simple network with one origin–destination (OD) pair connected by parallel links, and discovered the property of constant volume–capacity (v/c) ratio for a specific toll road operated by a private firm. Yang et al. (2009) further found the same property in their numerical example on a more general network. Wu et al. (2011a) rigorously demonstrated the existence of the constant v/c ratio property over a general transportation network by assuming that the UE link flow on the toll road is continuously differentiable with respect to its capacity and toll charge. It is an open and interesting question whether this important property still holds without the continuously differentiable assumption on the UE link flow. In this paper, we will first build a nonlinear programming model which is equivalent to the bi-level programming model formulated to determine the optimal choice of capacity and toll charge for a specific toll link operated by a particular private firm. The nonlinear programming model enables us to prove that the constant v/c ratio property does hold over a general transportation network without assuming the continuous differentiability of the UE link flow. In other words, the constant v/c ratio issue is solved completely under some mild conditions. In addition, we further examine whether the v/c ratio remains unchanged under a number of regulations and scenarios using the nonlinear programming model proposed in this study. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the bi-level programming model to determine the optimal choice of capacity and toll charge for a particular toll road. Section 3 develops an equivalent nonlinear programming model of the bi-level programming model presented in Section 2. Section 4 shows the existence of the constant v/c ratio without the continuously differentiable assumption on the UE link flow. Sections 5 and 6 further examine the v/c ratio issue under different regulations and scenarios. Section 7 summarizes the fundamental properties of the v/c ratio under these regulations and scenarios, and discusses their policy implications. Conclusions are presented in Section 8. 2 Notation, assumptions and problem description Consider a general transportation network denoted by G = (N, A) with a set of toll links (or roads) denoted by A ¯ , where N is the set of nodes, A is the set of links and the set of toll links A ¯ ⊂ A . It is assumed that each toll link a ∈ A ¯ is controlled and operated by one individual private firm and its capacity c a and toll charge τ a are determined by the firm itself. This type of network characterizes a transportation network with multiple build–operate–transfer (BOT) roads in practice. For the transportation network G, let W ⊂ N × N be the set of origin–destination (OD) pairs, R w be the set of paths between OD pair w ∈ W, d w denote the fixed travel demand between the OD pair w ∈ W , f r w be the traffic flow on the path r ∈ R w and v a be the traffic flow on link a ∈ A. Let δ ar w be a binary coefficient which equals 1 if link a ∈ A is on the path r ∈ R w between OD pair w ∈ W and 0 otherwise. Let t a (v a , c a ) be the travel time function on link a ∈ A with capacity c a . It is also assumed that the link travel time function t a (v a , c a ) is strictly increasing and convex with respect to the link flow v a . Moreover, t a (v a , c a ) is assumed to be continuously differentiable with respect to the link flow v a and link capacity c a . For the sake of presentation, it is assumed that the network users are homogeneous with the value-of-time (VOT) equal to 1 and their behavior in route choice between an OD pair follows the UE principle based on the generalized link travel time: (1) t ˆ a ( v a , c a ) = t a ( v a , c a ) + τ a , a ∈ A ¯ t a ( v a , c a ) , a ∈ A ⧹ A ¯ Without loss of generality, we focus on a particular toll link a ¯ , i.e., a ¯ ∈ A ¯ . For any given vector of capacities of all the other toll links excluding link a ¯ ∈ A ¯ , denoted by c - = ( c a , a ∈ A ¯ ⧹ { a ¯ } ) , and given vector of tolls of the toll links other than a ¯ ∈ A ¯ , denoted by τ - = ( τ a , a ∈ A ¯ ⧹ { a ¯ } ) , it is assumed that the capacity and toll for the toll link a ¯ ∈ A ¯ are determined by the relevant private firm to maximize its profit generated from the toll road (profit maximization or PM for short), namely: (2) [ PM ] Profit 1 ∗ = max τ a ¯ , c a ¯ Profit 1 ( τ a ¯ , c a ¯ ) = τ a ¯ v a ¯ UE ( τ a ¯ , τ - , c a ¯ , c - ) - κ a ¯ c a ¯ (3) subject to c a ¯ , τ a ¯ ⩾ 0 where κ a ¯ > 0 is the construction cost per unit capacity and v a ¯ UE ( τ a ¯ , c a ¯ , τ - , c - ) is the UE link flow on the link a ¯ , which can be obtained by solving the following user equilibrium problem with respect to a given vector of capacities and tolls ( τ a ¯ , τ - , c a ¯ , c - ) : (4) [ UE ] min ∑ a ∈ A ⧹ A ¯ ∫ 0 v a t a ( x , c a ) dx + ∑ a ∈ A ¯ ∫ 0 v a [ t a ( x , c a ) + τ a ] dx (5) subject to ∑ r ∈ R w f r w = d w , ∀ w ∈ W (6) v a = ∑ w ∈ W ∑ r ∈ R w δ ar w f r w , ∀ a ∈ A (7) f r w ⩾ 0 , ∀ r ∈ R w , ∀ w ∈ W Based on the conventional assumptions made on the link travel time functions, it can be seen that the UE link flow v a ¯ UE ( τ a ¯ , τ - , c a ¯ , c - ) is a continuous function of link toll and capacity, ( τ a ¯ , c a ¯ ) in accordance to the continuity analysis of UE link flows by Hall (1978). The bi-level programming model thus has at least one optimal solution provided that the link toll and capacity both have an upper bound. Such a bound does exist in reality. The bi-level programming model [PM] represented by Eqs. (2)–(7) may admit multiple optimal solutions, c a ¯ ∗ 1 , τ a ¯ ∗ 1 , v a ¯ ∗ 1 , c a ¯ ∗ 2 , τ a ¯ ∗ 2 , v a ¯ ∗ 2 , etc. The theorems developed in this paper apply to each optimal solution. To facilitate the presentation, the paper focuses on a particular optimal solution, represented as c a ¯ ∗ , τ a ¯ ∗ , v a ¯ ∗ , where the optimal link flow v a ¯ ∗ = v a ¯ UE τ a ¯ ∗ , τ - , c a ¯ ∗ , c - . We make the following reasonable and practical assumption: Assumption 1 The optimal link capacity c a ¯ ∗ > 0 , the optimal toll charge τ a ¯ ∗ > 0 , the optimal link flow v a ¯ ∗ > 0 , and the optimal value of objective function shown in Eq. (2), Profit 1 ∗ , satisfies the condition: (8) 0 < Profit 1 ∗ < + ∞ It is reasonable and practical to assume that the optimal capacity c a ¯ ∗ > 0 and optimal toll τ a ¯ ∗ > 0 because c a ¯ ∗ = 0 implies that link a ¯ does not exist and τ a ¯ ∗ = 0 means there is no revenue. Likewise, the practical transportation implementations also suggest that the optimal value of objective function (2) should also be positive and limited. This postulate makes us further assume that there is at least one path between each OD pair in the network which does not traverse the toll link a ¯ . 3 An equivalent nonlinear programming model Before building an equivalent nonlinear programming formulation for the bi-level programming model [PM] expressed by Eqs. (2)–(7), we first present the following three important lemmas. However, the sensitivity analysis of UE link flow (e.g., Tobin and Friesz, 1988; Yang and Bell, 2007) claims that the UE link flow v a ¯ UE τ a ¯ , τ - , c a ¯ , c - may be non-differentiable with respect to the capacity c a ¯ and/or the toll τ a ¯ . We now design the following example to show that the UE link flow v a ¯ UE ( τ a ¯ , τ - , c a ¯ , c - ) is non-differentiable at the optimal toll and capacity τ a ∗ , c a ∗ . Example 1 Consider a simple example shown in Fig. 1 having one OD pair connected by two parallel links, and only link 1 is a toll link with the toll of τ 1. The two link travel time functions, OD demand and unit construction cost are also illustrated in Fig. 1. Using Theorem 1, the conclusions in Wu et al. (2011a) can still be derived even if the UE link flow is non-differentiable. Moreover, even if there is more than one optimal solution to the bi-level programming model [PM], the v/c ratios associated with all the optimal solutions are the same. 5 Volume–capacity ratios under various government regulations We now proceed to investigate various regulatory mechanisms established by the government that may affect the choice of toll and capacity by the private firm. The impacts of these regulations on the v/c ratio of the link operated by the private firm are examined under each circumstance. 5.1 Rate-of-return regulation We first investigate a rate-of-return (ROR) regulatory mechanism, under which an upper bound is predetermined for the ROR of a private firm. The private firm is free to choose the toll and capacity as long as its profit does not exceed this upper bound. Let s denote the ROR on the firm’s investment and s ∗, s ∗ ⩾0, be the largest ROR determined by the government. Let τ a ¯ ∗ ROR and v a ¯ ∗ ROR be the optimal toll and flow under the ROR regulation, respectively. Suppose that the price ceiling is τ ˆ a ¯ . Let τ a ¯ ∗ PC and v a ¯ ∗ PC be the optimal toll and flow under the price-cap regulation, respectively. The first-order optimality condition of [PC] is (37) v a ¯ ∗ PC ∂ t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ PC , c a ¯ ∂ c a ¯ + κ a ¯ + λ - ∂ t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ PC , c a ¯ ∂ c a ¯ = 0 namely, (38) v a ¯ ∗ PC c a ¯ 2 dt a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ PC c a ¯ d v a ¯ ∗ PC c a ¯ = κ a ¯ + λ v a ¯ ∗ PC ( c a ¯ ) 2 dt a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ PC c a ¯ d ( v a ¯ ∗ PC / c a ¯ ) Evidently, the v/c ratio increases when λ >0. 5.3 Capacity regulation Assuming that the government regulates that c a ¯ ⩾ c ˆ a ¯ . Let v a ¯ ∗ CA be the optimal flow under the capacity regulation. The profit maximization problem for the private firm is (39) [ CA ] min c a ¯ > 0 v a ¯ ∗ CA t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ CA , c a ¯ + κ a ¯ c a ¯ (40) subject to c ˆ a ¯ - c a ¯ ⩽ 0 Let λ ⩾0 be the Lagrangian multiplier association with constraint (40). The first-order optimality condition of model [CA] is (41) v a ¯ ∗ CA ∂ t a ¯ ( v a ¯ ∗ CA , c a ¯ ) ∂ c a ¯ + κ a ¯ - λ = 0 Clearly, the v/c ratio decreases when λ >0. 5.4 Demand regulation Under the demand regulation by the government, the private firm is allowed to set the toll and capacity subject to the resultant UE traffic volume v a ¯ ∗ DM ⩾ v ˆ a ¯ , where v ˆ a ¯ is stipulated by the government. In this setting, the profit maximization model [P] does not change and thereby the v/c ratio remains unchanged. 5.5 Markup charge regulation Under a markup charge regulation, the private firm is allowed to earn a certain amount of profit on each unit of output it sells in an economic setting, denoted by p ˆ . This is equivalent to the return-on-output (ROO) regulation (Train, 1991). Let τ a ¯ ∗ MU and v a ¯ ∗ MU be the optimal toll and flow under the markup charge regulation, respectively. The profit maximization problem for the private firm is (42) [ MU ] min c a ¯ > 0 v a ¯ ∗ MU t a ¯ ( v a ¯ ∗ MU , c a ¯ ) + κ a ¯ c a ¯ (43) subject to τ a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ MU - κ a ¯ c a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ MU ⩽ p ˆ Eq. (43) can be rewritten as (44) t a ¯ ( v a ¯ ∗ MU , c a ¯ ) v a ¯ ∗ MU + κ a ¯ c a ¯ ⩾ τ a ¯ ∗ MU + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ MU , c a ¯ ∗ MU v a ¯ ∗ MU - p ˆ v a ¯ ∗ MU The left-hand side of Eq. (44) is identical to the objective function (42). Hence, the v/c ratio remains unchanged. 5.6 Social cost minimization scheme Now assume that the government requires that the private firm must choose the capacity and toll such that the total social cost is minimized (we assume that the government subsidizes the private firm if it loses money). Let v a ∗ SC , a ∈ A , be the optimal flow under the social cost minimization scheme. Note that the network flow is still in UE. The optimization problem is: (45) [ SC ] min c a ¯ > 0 ∑ a ∈ A ⧹ { a ¯ } v a ∗ SC t a v a ∗ SC + v a ¯ ∗ SC t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ SC , c a ¯ + κ a ¯ c a ¯ The first term in the objective function (45) is constant. Hence, model [SC] and [P] have the same structure and therefore the v/c ratio does not change. 6 Volume–capacity ratios in more general cases We now relax the assumptions under which we derive the constant v/c ratio in Sections 2–4. We would relax the assumption of constant returns to scale in road construction, continuous road capacity, and separable link travel time functions. Whether the v/c ratio remains constant is examined under the relaxation of the assumptions. 6.1 Effect of returns to scale in road construction We have examined the v/c ratio under constant returns to scale in road construction by assuming that the construction cost I ( c a ¯ ) = κ a ¯ c a ¯ . To look into the effects of decreasing and increasing returns to scale in road construction, we consider the following specific construction cost function (46) I ( c a ¯ ) = κ a ¯ ( c a ¯ ) α , α > 0 Road construction exhibits decreasing returns to scale when α >1 and increasing returns to scale when 0< α <1. Similarly, to derive the relationship between the volume and flow, the first-order optimality condition for the nonlinear programming model [P] is (47) v a ¯ ∗ c a ¯ 2 dt a ( v a ¯ ∗ / c a ¯ ) d ( v a ¯ ∗ / c a ¯ ) = κ a ¯ α ( c a ¯ ) α - 1 , α > 0 It is not difficult to see that the v/c ratio is no longer constant. 6.2 Impact of discrete road capacity In the setting of constant returns to scale in road construction, suppose that c a ¯ can only take discrete values (e.g., integer number of lanes). One might be attempted to conclude that the v/c ratio would still be independent of other links. However, this is not true. For example, consider a traffic network with two nodes and two links a ¯ and a, each from the origin to the destination. Assume that t a ¯ ( v a ¯ , c a ¯ ) = 1 + ( v a ¯ / c a ¯ ) 2 , OD demand q w =1000, κ a ¯ = 1 . Suppose that c a ¯ has to be a multiple of 500 units. When the generalized travel time on link a is t ˆ a ( v a , c a = 500 ) = 3 + ( v a / 500 ) 2 , we have c a ¯ ∗ = 500 , τ a ¯ ∗ = 3 and v a ¯ ∗ / c a ¯ ∗ = 0.75 . When t ˆ a ( v a , c a = 500 ) = 6 + ( v a / 500 ) 2 , we have c a ¯ ∗ = 1000 , τ a ¯ ∗ = 4 and v a ¯ ∗ c a ¯ ∗ = 1 . Therefore, the v/c ratio is no longer independent of the properties of other links. 6.3 Result of link interactions With continuous road capacity and constant returns to scale in road construction, the v/c ratio is no longer constant when link interactions are involved. A simple counter-example is as follows. Let v a ∗ LI , a ∈ A, be the optimal flow considering link interactions. Assume that the travel time function on link a ¯ , t a ¯ ( v a ¯ , v a , c a ¯ ) , is related to another link a and has the expression (48) t a ¯ ( v a ¯ , v a , c a ¯ ) = t a ¯ 0 + 0.15 v a ¯ + 0.1 v a c a ¯ 4 Considering Eq. (27), the first-order optimality condition for [P] is (49) v a ¯ ∗ LI v a ¯ ∗ LI + 0.1 v a ∗ LI ( c a ¯ ) 2 dt a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ LI + 0.1 v a ∗ LI c a ¯ d v a ¯ ∗ LI + 0.1 v a ∗ LI c a ¯ = κ a ¯ Therefore the v/c ratio is no longer constant. 7 Discussions Sections 5 and 6 show that the v/c ratio is a constant under the demand regulation, markup charge regulation, and social cost minimization scheme. However, the v/c ratio may change under the rate-of-return regulation, and it may decrease under capacity regulation and increase under the price-cap regulation. Moreover, it will change if there are decreasing or increasing returns to scale in road construction, or the road capacity can only take an integer number of lanes, or link interactions are involved. For the elastic OD demand pattern, we can use the excess-demand network representation to equivalently transform the UE problem with elastic demand to a standard UE problem (Sheffi, 1985). Therefore, the v/c ratio is still constant. These findings are summarized in Table 1 . The results shown in Table 1 can help the government to assess/ensure the level of service represented by the v/c ratio for the private toll road. For example, the level of service under the price-cap regulation may be lower than regulating nothing. However, the capacity regulation may make the level of service increase depending on the choice of the minimum road capacity. The constant v/c ratio makes it easy for private firms to estimate the maintenance cost as it would be proportional to the road capacity. The constant v/c ratio may guide us to design some efficient solution algorithms for the BOT project selection (Wu et al., 2011b) or toll design. 8 Conclusions We have derived the relationship between the volume and capacity of a private toll road in a general network. Under the assumption of continuous road capacity, constant returns to scale in road construction, and separable link travel time functions that are homogeneous of degree zero with respect to link flow and capacity, this paper has proved that the level of service, represented by the v/c ratio, offered by a profit maximizing private firm on a private toll road is independent of any another competitor’s choice of capacity and toll rate for another private toll road. We have extended the work by Wu et al. (2011a) without the assumption that the link flow is continuously differentiable with respect to the generalized link travel cost. We have further analyzed a number of regulations and scenarios and identified whether the v/c ratio remains unchanged and examined some policy implications of the v/c ratio. Appendix A Proof of Lemma 1 Proof Point (i) of Lemma 1 is obvious due to the positive toll revenue of the private firm gained from the toll link. We prove Point (ii) of Lemma 1 by contradiction. Denote by W ¯ ⊆ W the set of OD pairs with positive flow on link a ¯ . If Point (ii) of Lemma 1 does not hold, then all the used paths r ∈ R w between an OD pair w ∈ W ¯ traverse link a ¯ , and their generalized travel times are strictly lower than the unused paths. Hence, if the private firm increases the toll τ a ¯ by a very small positive value such that the used paths still have the lowest generalized travel time, the UE flow will not change whereas the private firms would obtain a higher profit. This contradicts the assumption that ( c a ¯ ∗ , τ a ¯ ∗ ) is the optimal solution.□ Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2 Proof Point (i) is evident because the UE condition still holds. To prove Points (ii) and (iii), for simplification let v a = v a UE τ a ¯ ∗ , τ - , c a ¯ ∗ , c - , Δ v a = V a ¯ UE τ a ¯ ∗ + δ , τ - , c a ¯ ∗ , c - - v a UE τ a ¯ ∗ , τ - , c a ¯ ∗ , c - , a ∈ A , and T a ¯ = t a ¯ v a ¯ UE τ a ¯ ∗ , τ - , c a ¯ ∗ , c - , c a ¯ + τ a ¯ ∗ . (5)–(7) form a polyhedron and both (v a ,a ∈ A) and (v a +Δv a ,a ∈ A) are feasible flow patterns, (v a +Δv a /2,a ∈ A) is also a feasible flow pattern. Therefore at least on one link Δv a must be non-zero. Given the strict convexity of the function ∫ 0 v a t a ( x , c a ) dx , we have (52) 2 ∑ a ∈ A ⧹ { a ¯ } ∫ 0 v a + Δ v a / 2 t a ( x , c a ) dx < ∑ a ∈ A ⧹ { a ¯ } ∫ 0 v a t a ( x , c a ) dx + ∑ a ∈ A ⧹ { a ¯ } ∫ 0 v a + Δ v a t a ( x , c a ) dx Summing up Eqs. (50)–(52), we have (53) ( T a ¯ + δ ) ( v a ¯ + Δ v a ¯ / 2 ) + T a ¯ ( v a ¯ + Δ v a ¯ / 2 ) > T a ¯ v a ¯ + ( T a ¯ + δ ) ( v a ¯ + Δ v a ¯ ) That is, (54) δ Δ v a ¯ < 0 which implies Points (ii) and (iii).□ Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3 Proof If the capacity c a ¯ and toll τ a ¯ satisfy τ a ¯ = τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ - t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ , the resultant UE flow on link a ¯ does not change as the UE condition still holds. Now suppose that τ a ¯ ≠ τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ - t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ , i.e., τ a ¯ = τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ - t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ + δ , δ ≠ 0 , and the resultant UE flow on link a ¯ does not change. Then according to Point (i) of Lemma 2, the resultant UE flow on link a ¯ does not change if we set the generalized travel time on link a ¯ at τ a ¯ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ = τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ + δ . However, according to Points (ii) and (iii) of Lemma 2, since the generalized travel time on link a ¯ is changed from τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ to τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ + δ , the resultant UE flow on link a ¯ must change. Therefore, as long as τ a ¯ ≠ τ a ¯ ∗ + t a ¯ v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ ∗ - t a ¯ ( v a ¯ ∗ , c a ¯ , the resultant UE flow on link a ¯ would change. coredata.dc:description: Abstract It has been addressed in the existing literature that the volume–capacity (v/c) ratio on a private toll road is constant, regardless of the toll value and capacity set by the private companies for each toll road in the network. The previous derivation depends on the assumption that the user equilibrium flow on the private toll road is continuously differentiable with respect to its capacity and toll charge. In this paper, it is shown that the constant v/c ratio phenomenon still holds via relaxing this assumption. Such phenomenon is further examined in different scenarios: the v/c ratio remains constant under the demand regulation, markup charge regulation, and social cost minimization scheme; it may change under the rate-of-return regulation; it may decrease under capacity regulation and increase under the price-cap regulation. Moreover, this paper demonstrates that the v/c ratio may change if there are decreasing or increasing returns to scale in road construction, or the road capacity can only take discrete values, or link flow interactions are involved, whereas the v/c ratio remains constant in case of elastic demand.
coredata.dc:title: Fundamental properties of volume–capacity ratio of a private toll road in general networks
